Expectation1: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation1: Product has scheduled a general brainstorming session next sprint where attendance is optional
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: At a communal event, the catered dishes lack certification and substituting food would be difficult.
Story: I scan the email from Product: “Next sprint, we’re holding a general brainstorming session—attendance optional, but we’d love your input!” I know these sessions are where new features are born, and as a developer, my voice matters. I want to be there, to collaborate, to help shape what we build next. But then I see the attached menu for the catered lunch: nothing is kosher-certified, and the options are all mixed or unclear. I picture the spread—sandwiches, salads, maybe some desserts—none of which I can eat. Bringing my own food would make me stand out, and skipping the meal would mean missing the informal conversations where ideas really flow. I feel the pressure from both sides: my team expects me to contribute, to be present, to help define our direction. My faith expects me to honor my dietary laws, to hold fast even when it’s inconvenient. I sit at my desk, torn, the invitation open on my screen, wondering how I can possibly meet both expectations.
